comments:
A general introduction to the scientific study of language structure, history, and use. Topics include notions of "grammar"; written versus spoken (and signed) language; the structure of sounds, words, sentences, and meanings; language in culture and society; language change over time; language acquisition and processing; comparison with non-human communication systems.  

Few students expressed favorable reactions to this course, claiming the material was “boring” or just not particularly stimulating. 

Students appreciated that Professor Liberman posted his lecture notes online but had a hard time paying attention in class when the professor read off these lecture notes or discussed tangential topics. Many found the material to be “dry.”

Reports of difficulty varied but many students commented that they found the course to be easy and not work-intensive. Many students took this course to fulfill the Sector VII requirement.
